column1: Citi Research says Apple will use tax reform proceeds to significantly increase its stock buyback and dividend program. Analyst predicts the company on its next earnings call will raise its capital return program to about $400 billion from its current $300 billion authorization. Apple is slated to report its fiscal second-quarter earnings results on May 1, according to its website. The company's stock rose 1.3 percent Thursday.
column2: Extra Space Storage Inc. declared a quarterly dividend of $0.78 per share on the common stock of the Company for the first quarter 2018. The dividend is payable on to stockholders of record at the close of business on . As of , the Company owned and/or operated 1,483 self-storage properties, which comprise approximately 1,020,000 units and 112 million square feet of rentable storage space.
column3: Erie Insurance announced Matt Palczer as vice president of property and subrogation. He began his career with Erie Insurance in 2002 as a mail clerk in Murrysville, Pa. He has served in positions of increasing responsibility including as a multi-line adjuster, property adjuster and property reinspector. He is currently pursuing a bachelor's degree at Southern New Hampshire University and is a United States Air Force veteran.
column4: "SportsCenter" is coming to the ESPN app. It will feature top plays, highlights and what fans should expect in the coming day. New episodes will be prominently featured on the home screen when users first open ESPN's app. The announcement follows the launch of a direct-to-consumer service in the U.S. for "cord-cutters" or those who primarily use mobile devices and computers.
column5: The United States supports Argentine President Mauricio Macri's economic reform program, the White House said. Buenos Aires announced this week it was seeking financing from the International Monetary Fund. "President Macri has the right vision for the Argentine economy and has made important strides toward modernizing the country's economic policy," it said. The U.S. and Argentina have a long-standing friendship.
column6: Oclaro Inc. (OCLR) on Tuesday reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $10.8 million. Earnings, adjusted for stock option expense and restructuring costs, came to 11 cents per share. The average estimate of eight analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research was for earnings of 8 cents. Oclaro shares have risen 26 percent since the beginning of the year.
column7: President Donald Trump says there could be a "phase two" of tax cuts. The nearly $1.5 trillion Republican tax bill, which is now the law of the land, cut corporate tax rates to 21 percent from 35 percent. Even with majorities in the Senate and the House, Republican lawmakers had a tough time passing the tax-cut bill in December, just in time for Trump to sign it before the new year.
column8: Micron also said it would buy back $10 billion of its shares. The stock is up nearly 35 percent this year through Monday.Intel shares are reacting more modestly, up 0.6 percent Tuesday after climbing 1.5 percent on Monday. For more on Micron, watch CEO Sanjay Mehrotra's interview on Mad Money tonight at 6 p.m. ET. Watch Micron-Intel announce shipment of new NAND chip show chapters.
column9: The Board of Directors of The Charles Schwab Corporation has declared a semi-annual dividend on the outstanding Fixed-to-Floating Rate Non-Cumulative Perpetual Preferred Stock, Series A in the amount of $35 per share. The dividend is payable , to stockholders of record at the close of business on . The company provides a full range of wealth management, securities brokerage, banking, money management, custody, and financial
column10: U.S. President Donald Trump says he will propose new tax cuts. Trump signed a $1.5 trillion tax cut in December, the signature legislative achievement of his presidency. All members of the House of Representatives and one-third of the Senate are up for re-election. Democrats must wrest 23 seats nationwide from Republicans to take over the 435-member House. In the Senate, Republicans control the chamber 51 to 49.
column11: The company has made a tender offer to the management of PTA Holdings, Inc. to acquire 100% of the Company's outstanding stock, liabilities and assets in exchange for $17 million in cash. The consolidation of interests is being done to benefit the many shareholders who invested in the company. The focus of the combined companies is to expand the company via a strategic transportation industry roll-up.
column12: Cadence Design Systems Inc. (CDNS) on Monday reported first-quarter net income of $72.9 million. The results beat Wall Street expectations. The maker of hardware and software products for validating chip designs posted revenue of $517.3 million. For the current quarter ending in July, Cadence expects its per-share earnings to range from 39 cents to 41 cents.
column13: Sen. Rand Paul was blocking the Senate's move to quickly pass approve its massive budget deal. The Kentucky Republican held out as he sought a vote on an amendment to maintain budget caps. The bill before the Senate would set up a roughly $300 billion increase in the budget caps over two years. The House would then have to pass it before midnight Thursday and send it to President Donald Trump for his signature.
column14: Vice President Mike Pence announced the sanctions on Pedro Luis Martin Olivares during a speech at the Organization of American States. Martin was indicted on 2015 by a grand jury in Florida for willfully conspiring to distribute a controlled substance into the United States. The action freezes any of their assets in the U.S. or held by people in theU.S., as well as 20 companies owned or controlled by these three individuals.
column15: Lumentum Holdings Inc. (LITE) reported fiscal third-quarter net income of $2.4 million. The optical networking products maker posted revenue of $298.8 million in the period. Lumentum expects its per-share earnings to range from 55 cents to 75 cents for the current quarter. The company said it expects revenue in the range of $275 million to $300 million for the fiscal fourth quarter.
column16: The European Commission has said it would respond "firmly" to proposed U.S. import duties of 25 percent on steel and 10 percent on aluminium. It has spelt out it would join others in a challenge at the World Trade Organization (WTO) and consider safeguard measures. A further counter-measure under consideration would specifically target the United States to "rebalance" trade between the two.
column17: Luminex Corporation's board of directors declared a cash dividend for the first quarter of 2018 of $0.06 per share of common stock. The dividend is payable on to stockholders of record as of the close of business on . At Luminex, our mission is to empower labs to obtain reliable, timely, and actionable answers, ultimately advancing health.
column18: Campbell Soup reported a 2 percent drop in organic net sales in its second quarter. Shares of the world's biggest soup maker fell 2.1 percent to $46.70 in premarket trading. Fewer orders from Walmart have weighed on Campbell's earnings in the reported quarter. Still, the company reported net sales that beat estimates marginally helped by a rise in demand for its Pepperidge Farm Snacks.
column19: Cisco pulls all online ads from YouTube due to fears of ads appearing on sensitive content. Cisco's action follows a CNN report in April that said ads from over 300 companies, including Cisco, ran on extremist channels on YouTube. YouTube said in a report released last month that it had deleted about 5 million videos from its platform for content policy violations in last year's fourth quarter before any viewers saw them.
column20: Reliance Steel & Aluminum Co. (RS) reported fourth-quarter earnings of $301.4 million. The results exceeded Wall Street expectations. The metals service-center company posted revenue of $2.38 billion in the period. Reliance Steel expects full-year earnings to be $1.90 to $2 per share. The stock has climbed 5 percent in the last 12 months.
column21: Foot Locker, Inc. declared a quarterly cash dividend of $0.345 per share. The dividend will be payable on to shareholders of record on . As of , the Company operated 3,284 stores in 24 countries in North America, Europe, Australia, and New Zealand. The Company is a leading provider of athletic footwear and apparel.
column22: Elkem plans to raise some 5 billion Norwegian crowns ($640.16 million) in an initial public offering. Current owner, China National Bluestar, will reduce its stake while remaining a long-term majority shareholder. Elkem's 2017 revenues rose to 21.4 billion crowns on a proforma basis, from 16.9 billion the previous year, it said.
column23: Snap-On shares soared more than 9 percent on Thursday. Earnings per share and revenues both beat analyst estimates. Snap-on's gains made it the biggest gainer in the S&P 500 on Thursday morning. Thursday morning's earnings announcement offsets the negative path the stock has been on since the beginning of the year. Shares have fallen 18 percent since the start of 2018. The company expects a 2018 effective income tax rate of 24 percent to 25 percent, lower than last year's
column24: North American Financial 15 Split Corp. declares its regular monthly distribution of $0.10000 for each Class A share ($1.20 annually) and $ 0.04583 for each Preferred share ($0.550 annually) Distributions are payable to shareholders on record as at . The Company invests in a high quality portfolio consisting of 15 financial services companies made up of Canadian and U.S. issuers.
column25: Eurocom Group, the parent company of Bezeq Israeli Telecom, has petitioned a Tel Aviv court to allow a debt settlement. Chairman Shaul Elovitch is under pressure to sell Eurocom, which is laden with nearly 1 billion shekels in debt. Under the proposal, a group led by U.S.-Israeli businessman Naty Saidoff would bring a "significant and rapid capital flow" to Eurocom.
column26: Twitter says it found a password bug and that you should change yours. Twitter says a bug caused it to store passwords improperly. It doesn't think user accounts were affected but recommends users change their passwords.Shares of Twitter dipped slightly in after-hours trading on the news. The company doesn't believe "information ever left Twitter's systems or was misused by anyone," but recommends you change your passwords and enable two factor authentication.
column27: The blood glucose monitor business generated net revenue of about $1.5 billion last year. J&J has until June 15 to accept the offer, unless it's extended. If accepted, the deal is expected to close by the end of the year. The transaction was included in the earnings forecast J&T gave in January. The offer was made by private equity firm Platinum Equity, which also owns Calibra Medical.
column28: Match Group (NASDAQ: MTCH) will audiocast a conference call to review its fourth quarter 2017 financial results on Wednesday, at 8:30 a.m. Eastern Time (ET) After the close of market trading on Tuesday, February 6, Match Group will publish itsFourth quarter results along with a supplemental investor presentation, which may include certain forward-looking information. The live audiocasts and replay will be open to the public at
column29: The worlds top smartphone rivals have been in court over patents since 2011. Apple filed a lawsuit alleging Samsungs smartphones and tablets slavishly copied its products. Samsung was found liable in a 2012 trial, but a disagreement over the amount to be paid led to the current retrial over damages where arguments ended on May 18. The jury has been deliberating the case since last week. of CNET: Jury says Samsung should pay Apple $539 million.
column30: Ralph Lauren said adjusted gross margin was 59.8 percent in the fourth quarter, a 440 basis point rise from a year earlier. The company incurred $322 million in restructuring charges in the year-ago quarter. Same-store sales on constant currency basis fell 1 percent, but less than the 2.3 percent fall expected byAnalysts on average had expected a profit of 83 cents per share.
column31: The Norwegian Bliss is the latest ship to join the company's fleet. The Bliss cost about $1 billion to build and is setting its sights to dethrone Carnival and Royal Caribbean. The cruise market totals close to $41.1 billion in wages and salaries. As for Carnival, Royal Caribbean and Norwegian; they control close to 80 percent of the cruise market space."The cruise industry is growing like a weed and every ship is full to the hilt," said Frank Del Rio
column32: Barclays says certain tech names have a history of bouncing back quickly after a market correction. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 are both down more than 6 percent over the past week. Both segments have historically captured more upside in the three months following the bottom of a correction than the market, the bank said in a note to clients. The report was published on Thursday.
column33: A US official called on Iran to unblock social media sites amid protests. U.S. Undersecretary of State Steve Goldstein said Instagram, Telegram and other platforms are "legitimate avenues for communication" The United States is encouraging Iranians to use virtual private networks, known as VPNs. The Trump administration is calling on Iran's government to stop blocking Instagram and other popular social media Sites.
column34: Mr. Kam Yuen, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of the Group, has further increased his shareholding in Golden Meditech. He acquired a total of 9,068,000 shares through Bio Garden Inc., his family-owned entity, on 9 March 2018 and 13 March 2018 respectively. Upon the acquisition and the cancellation of the repurchased Taiwan depository receipts shares, Mr. Yuen and his concert parties hold an aggregate of 2,096,111,560 shares
column35: Universal Health Services (NYSE: UHS) is one of the largest and most respected hospital management companies in the nation. For nearly 40 years, UHS and its affiliates have focused on meeting patients' healthcare needs across hundreds of local communities. UHS subsidiaries own and/or operate 357 inpatient and outpatient facilities including acute care hospitals, behavioral health facilities, ambulatory centers, freestanding emergency departments, and urgent care centers.
column36: Vector Group Ltd. will conduct a conference call and webcast to discuss its fourth quarter and full-year 2017 results on Thursday, at 8:30 a.m. (ET) Investors can access the call by dialing 800-859-8150 and entering 99976716 as the conference ID number. The call will also be available via live webcast at
column37: After the close of market trading on Wednesday, February 7, IAC will post its fourth quarter results and simultaneously IAC's CEO, Joey Levin, will publish a letter to shareholders. Going forward, in addition to the Match Group conference call, ANGI Homeservices will host a quarterly conference call in which IAC executives will also participate to answer questions regarding IAC. The Match group conference call will be held Wednesday, Feb. 7, 2018 at 8:30 a.m
column38: Tahoe Resources Inc. plans to release its first quarter 2018 financial and operating results on Wednesday, after the market close. On Thursday, at 10:00am ET, Tahoe will hold a conference call and audio webcast to discuss the results. Tahoe is a member of the S&P/TSX Composite and TSX Global Mining indices and the GDX and Russell 3000 on the NYSE.
column39: IBM announced revenue growth from the year-ago quarter for the first time in more than five years. The company will hold a teleconference with analysts at 5 p.m. Eastern time. Analysts expect IBM to report gains from companies upgrading to IBM's latest mainframe computer, the z14. IBM stock is up 4 percent since the beginning of the year, according to Thomson Reuters.
column40: The rand was 0.35 percent weaker at 12.0750 per dollar compared to an overnight close of 12.0375 in New York. Data on Tuesday showed manufacturing down on a month on month basis in February following a similarly poor print in the previous month. The Reserve Bank warned that 2017's boom could fade if details on policy reforms were not forthcoming. Stocks opened weaker at 0700 GMT, with the blue-chip Top-40 Index down 0.2 percent.
column41: EastGroup Properties, Inc. is a self-administered equity real estate investment trust focused on the development, acquisition and operation of industrial properties in major Sunbelt markets. EastGroup has increased or maintained its dividend for 25 consecutive years. The Company has increased it 22 years over that period, including increases in each of the last six years.EastGroup's portfolio, including development projects in lease-up and under construction, currently includes 39.5 million square feet.
column42: Rudy Giuliani is conducting question-and-answer sessions with President Donald Trump, according to an NBC News reporter. The sessions are "to educate me" about what he can say that is not protected by attorney-client privilege, Giuliani told the NBC reporter. Giuliani joined Trump's legal team in April and is preparing the president for an interview with the special counsel, the reporter said.
column43: GoPro Inc. (GPRO) on Thursday reported a loss of $76.3 million in its first quarter. On a per-share basis, the San Mateo, California-based company said it had a Loss of 55 cents. In the final minutes of trading on Thursday, the company's shares hit $4.96. A year ago, they were trading at $8.40.
column44: Iconix Brand Group, Inc. plans to report its fourth quarter and full year ended financial results on Wednesday, . The Company will not be hosting a conference call at this time. Iconix owns, licenses and markets a portfolio of consumer brands including: CANDIE'S, BONGO, RAMPAGE, MUDD, LONDON FOG, ROCAWEAR, and ARTFUL DODGER.
column45: Rowley Law PLLC is investigating potential claims against Key Technology, Inc. and its board of directors for breach of fiduciary duty. The proposed acquisition of the company by Duravant LLC is valued at approximately $175 million. Stockholders will receive $26.75 for each share of Key Technology Inc. that they hold. If you are a stockholder and are interested in obtaining additional information regarding this investigation, please visit us at:
column46: SunPower Corp will buy U.S. panel maker SolarWorld Americas. The news sent SunPower's shares up 12 percent on the Nasdaq. SunPower is based in San Jose, California but most of its manufacturing is in the Philippines and Mexico. The SolarWorld facility in Hillsboro, Oregon, will be retrofitted to produce Sun Power's panels but will continue to make SolarWorld's legacy products as well.
column47: The Company will release first quarter 2018 financial results after the market closes on Tuesday, . A conference call will be held the next day on Wednesday, , at 1:00 p.m. Eastern Time to review the Company's first quarter results, discuss recent events and conduct a question-and-answer period. To listen to a live broadcast, go to the site at least 15 minutes prior to the scheduled start time.
column48: Intel's stock surged to its highest levels since September 2000 on Friday. The company beat Wall Street estimates when it reported earnings Thursday. Intel also raised its dividend 10 percent in response to the GOP tax bill, adding to a growing list of companies that have returned tax savings to employees or shareholders. The stock is up more than 7 percent year to date and more than 30 percent in the last 12 months.
column49: The bank said it is recommitting to New York City with the project. Construction begins next year, and eventually the new building will house 15,000 employees. The current building at Park Avenue between 47th and 48th Streets was constructed in 1950 and meant for 3,500 employees. About 8,000 construction-related jobs will be created for the five-year project. The bank says it won't have any material effect on its financial results.
column50: Allergan expects the move to save it $300 million to $400 million this year. It anticipates the changes will cost $125 million, mainly due to severance expenses. The company said in November that it would undertake a cost-cutting and restructuring program.Shares of Allergan have fallen more than 20 percent in the last 12 months. They were up 1.1 percent midday Wednesday.
column51: The move is the first concrete step that Comcast is taking to upend Disney's deal with Fox. Comcast has already made a 22 billion pound ($30 billion) offer to acquire the 61 percent stake in European pay-TV group Sky that Fox does not already own. Fox rejected an offer from Comcast last year largely due to antitrust concerns, and Comcast plans to make a new offer only if AT&T and Time Warner prevail in court.
column52: SSENSE, a pioneering fashion platform with global reach, announced today that it has acquired the social-commerce website, Polyvore, from Oath Inc. effective immediately. SSENSE is pacing the vanguard of directional retail with its mix of luxury, streetwear, and avant-garde labels. Currently serving 114 countries, generating an average of 53 million monthly page views, and achieving high double digit annual growth.
column53: Airbnb matches people wishing to rent out all or part of their homes to temporary guests. A hearing at a Paris court is scheduled for June 12. Earlier this month, a Singapore court fined two Airbnb hosts a total of $45,800 each for unauthorized short-term letting. France is Airbnb's second-largest market after the U.S., with around 65,000 homes listed.
column54: Illumina and Ariosa compete in the growing market for non-invasive prenatal tests. Ariosa Diagnostics, a subsidiary of Roche Holdings AG, acquired Ariosa for $625 million in January 2015. The jury rejected a counterclaim by Ariosa that Illumina had breached a contract between the companies by bringing the lawsuit. The two companies did not immediately respond to requests for comment.
column55: Workday Inc. (WDAY) on Thursday reported a loss of $74.4 million in its fiscal first quarter. On a per-share basis, the Pleasanton, California-based company said it had a Loss of 35 cents. Earnings, adjusted for stock option expense and non-recurring costs, came to 33 cents per share.The results beat Wall Street expectations.
column56: 'Bad' incentives, poor communication behind the Wells Fargo sales scandal: Fed's Dudley. The bank reached a $190 million settlement with U.S. authorities in 2016 over its employees opening accounts in customers' names without their permission to hit sales targets. The Federal Reserve Bank of New York president said that Wells Fargo employees were given "really bad" incentives. He added that when employees complained, it went up the chain of command but concerns either were not heard or ignored.
column57: Dorel Industries will hold a conference call on Friday, at 10:45am Eastern Time. The conference call is open to: Analysts, investors and all interested parties. Please dial in 15 minutes before the conference begins. If you are unable to call in at this time, you may access a recording of the meeting by calling 1-800-585-8367 and entering the passcode 6668808 on your phone. This recording will be available on
column58: The S&P 500 fell officially into correction territory on Thursday, down more than 10 percent from its record reached in January. The biggest question investors are asking is how much further will the market fall before resuming its march higher. Citi Research strategist Tobias Levkovich showed the numbers behind all the market corrections in the S-P 500 since Dec. 1927 in a note to clients Monday. The firm found 40 instances when the market declined 10 percent or more.
column59: New Jersey Gov. Phil Murphy says the state needs relief from the "horrific" Republican tax law. "We'll do what it takes to push back on this," Murphy said. The central issue is the new $10,000 cap on property, state and local income tax deductions. New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo announced New York, New Jersey and Connecticut plan to sue the federal government.
column60: Cramer: Deere is a good company for the long term because it feeds the world. Henry Schein: "You can hold it long term. I think Align Technology has more growth. It's better and so is Zoetis ."Fitbit: "Don't pull the trigger. There's so many other, better plays than Fitbit."Splunk: "I was going to actually tell the [ActionAlertsPlus.com club] gang that we ought to
column61: Nordson will release second quarter fiscal year 2018 earnings on Monday, after the close of the market. Nordson will host its quarterly webcast on Tuesday, at 8:30am ET. The webcast will be archived until Tuesday, . The company engineers, manufactures and markets differentiated products and systems used to dispense, apply and control adhesives, coatings, polymers and other fluids.
column62: Distribuidora de Gas del Centro cancels plans to list its shares on the Buenos Aires stock exchange. "Market volatility" prompted the decision, according to a letter posted on the CNV market regulator's website. The cancellation is the latest in a series of disappointments for Argentine companies. Argentina shares have slid 4.2 percent in March, although they are still up 5.2% so far this year.
column63: Purcell Julie & Lefkowitz LLP is investigating a potential breach of fiduciary duty claim involving the board of directors of Aevi Genomic Medicine, Inc. (NASDAQ: GNMX) If you are a shareholder and are interested in obtaining additional information regarding this investigation, please visit us at:
column64: Tanzania's energy regulator raises maximum price for petrol, diesel and kerosene. Fuel prices have a big influence on the inflation rate in the East African country. In the 12 months through November inflation eased to 4.4 percent, from 5.1 percent the previous month. Analysts say the fuel price hikes could push the inflation rates up again, analysts said in a report.
column65: CTS Corporation will release earnings for the fourth quarter and full year 2017 at approximately 8:00 a.m. (EST) on Tuesday, . A conference call to discuss financial results with management is scheduled for Tuesday, Feb. 6, at 11:00 p.m (EST). A live audio webcast of the conference call will be available and can be accessed directly from the Investors section of the website of CTS Corporation at
column66: McConnell says he wants to handle DACA and government spending separately. The bill would tackle the status of young immigrants whose protection from potential deportation under the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals, or DACA, program ends in March. "And my assumption is that will include not only some kind of DACA solution, but additional items," he said in a speech to the Senate on Tuesday. The Senate Republican leader was speaking to reporters.
column67: ARC Document Solutions, Inc. will hold a conference call with investors and analysts on Tuesday, , at 2 P.M. Pacific Time. The company will discuss the results of the company's 2018 first quarter ending . To access the live audio call, dial 800-239-9838. International callers may join the conference by dialing +1 323-794-2551.
column68: New Zealand's overseas investment regulator is investigating Agria Corporation. The move comes after Agria was delisted from the New York Stock Exchange last year. The OIO can block investments if it finds that foreign owners are not of "good character" It recently turned down Chinese conglomerate HNA Group's bid to purchase Australia and New Zealand Banking's asset finance firm UDC Finance. The regulator is also using the character test as grounds to probe American television personality Matt Lauer's ownership of a
column69: Sanmina Corp. (SANM) reported a fiscal first-quarter loss of $154.9 million. The electronics manufacturing services company posted revenue of $1.74 billion. For the current quarter ending in April, Sanmina expects its per-share earnings to range from 40 cents to 50 cents. The company said it expects revenue in the range of $2.7 billion for the fiscal second quarter.
column70: Holly Energy Partners, L.P. plans to announce results for its quarter ended on , before the opening of trading on the NYSE. The Partnership has scheduled a webcast conference to discuss financial results. The webcast may be accessed at:
column71: RPC, Inc. announced today that its Board of Directors approved an increase of 10.0 million shares to its stock buyback program. This authorization is part of a broader capital allocation framework to deliver value to shareholders by returning excess cash to shareholders through share repurchases and dividends. RPC provides a broad range of specialized oilfield services and equipment primarily to independent and major oilfield companies.
column72: The clock is 500 feet tall and powered by the Earth's thermal cycles. The century hand advances once every 100 years, and the cuckoo comes out on the millennium. The clock has been in the works for nearly three decades, according to a blog post signed by Amazon's Jeff Bezos. "Building a Clock inside a remote mountain is a big task," the post reads. "We're making progress every day"
column73: PotlatchDeltic Corporation (NASDAQ:PCH) will release first quarter earnings on Thursday, May 3rd, after the market closes. A live conference call and webcast will be hosted by Michael J. Covey, chairman and chief executive officer on Friday, May 4th at 9:00 a.m. Pacific Time (12:00 pm Eastern Time) A replay of the conference call will be available two hours following the call until .
column74: 500.com Limited (NYSE: WBAI) filed its annual report on Form 20-F for the fiscal year ended with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission on . The annual report, which contains its audited financial statements, can be accessed on the SEC's website at as well as via the Company's investor relations website. 500.com was among the first companies to provide online lottery services
column75: Tech sector fell more than 2 percent on Monday, after growing scrutiny over Facebook 's data-sharing practices. But according to a top technician there's one name in the space that's gearing up for a big breakout when it reports earnings Monday after the bell. Carter Worth, head of technical analysis at Cornerstone Macro, noted that over the last 10 years Oracle has underperformed the broader tech sector by 50 percent.
column76: Canada Goose Holdings: "I just reiterated [my call on] Goose last week when it dropped to $32" Honeywell Intl: "Don't forget, [CEO] Darius Adamczyk is doing some nice moves, getting out value" Marathon Petroleum Corporation: "That is the best-managed refiner there is and I continue to recommend it" Zagg: "The guy I really liked there, the CEO, he stepped down. He retired, and that was one
column77: Gilead Sciences says fourth-quarter sales of its flagship hepatitis C drugs fell by more than half. The company forecast a further slowdown next year, sending its shares lower after the closing bell. Gilead, which last year paid nearly $12 billion for cancer immunotherapy company Kite Pharma, said it earned $1.78 a share in the fourth quarter after one-time items. For full-year 2018, the biotechnology company forecast product sales of $20 billion to
column78: Arcadia Inc. announced that it has acquired the assets of Metal Window Corporation, a leading Southern California manufacturer of unique, high-quality aluminum window and door products. This acquisition will expand and enhance the capabilities of Arcadia's Residential Division, Arcadia Custom. It allows Arcadia to better serve its expanding nationwide luxury home market. Arcadia will continue to offer Metal Window's unique high- quality products along with their premier thermal aluminum, thermal steel and wood window and doors.
column79: Russia says International Olympic Committee has reinstated its membership. Russians competed as neutrals in the 2018 Pyeongchang Winter Olympics after the IOC suspended Russia in December. The IOC said it had found evidence of an "unprecedented systematic manipulation" of the anti-doping system. The Russian Olympic Committee said the decision was "of the utmost importance for us" and that its rights had been fully restored.
column80: Roku shares gained nearly 5 percent after hours. Hostess Brands rallied 3 percent in after-hours trading.Qualcomm stock hiked 2 percent post-market after the chipmaker announced a $10 billion stock buyback. Nuance Communications stock plunged 11 percent in the extended session after the company gave disappointing guidance. The company said it expects adjusted third-quarter earnings between 25 cents and 28 cents per share.
column81: Atlassian's stock has been on a hot streak, more than doubling in the past year. On Thursday, it closed at a record of $55.60 before dipping after its earnings report. The company's operating loss widened to $15.3 million from $2.6 million, as operating expenses jumped by almost 50 percent.Atlassian also said that its marketplace of business apps surpassed a new revenue milestone during the quarter, reaching $350 million in lifetime sales.
column82: Jay Leno has millions in the bank, but he doesn't always spend like a millionaire. He hates spending on clothes and still hasn't touched a dime of his "Tonight Show" money. "I'm not a big splurge guy," Leno tells CNBC Make It , partly because he had Depression-era parents: "They just frightened me to death, saying, 'You gotta save every penny!'"
column83: American Airlines had 89 departures to an equal number of arrivals scheduled from Boston's Logan International Airport on Tuesday. The airline and the regional carriers that operate some of its routes will not fly to and from Boston because of the storm. Several airlines with large operations from Boston, including American, Delta and JetBlue , are waiving ticket-change fees for travelers affected by storm. About a fifth of flights scheduled for Tuesday are already canceled, FlightAware says.
column84: Tronox Limited announces fourth quarter and full-year 2017 earnings release and webcast conference call. Earnings Release: Tuesday, , after the market close via PR Newswire and the Tronox Limited website: tronox.com. Conference Call: Wednesday, ,. at 8:30 a.m. ET (New York). The live call is open to the public via internet broadcast and telephone.
column85: The lack of growth in U.S. manufacturing confounded analyst expectations for a 0.3 percent monthly gain. The industrial sector has received support over the last year from a strengthening global economy. Overall industrial production fell 0.1 percent in January, dragged down by a 1.0 percent decline in mining output.Capacity utilization, a measure of how fully industries are deploying their resources, fell to 77.5 percent.
column86: Anadarko Petroleum Corp reported a quarterly profit that beat analysts' estimate. Oil prices have recovered from the depths hit in 2016 and are trading around $70. This helped the shale oil producer sell oil at $63.66 per barrel, up from $50.34 a year earlier. Oil production fell 19 percent to 643,000 barrels per day during the first three months of 2018.
column87: Inogen Inc. (INGN) on Monday reported first-quarter profit of $10.8 million. The Goleta, California-based company said it had net income of 48 cents per share. Inogen expects full-year revenue in the range of $310 million to $320 million. In the final minutes of trading on Monday, shares hit $140.58, a climb of 70 percent in the last 12 months.
column88: Barclays CEO Jes Staley has no plans to leave the British bank despite an ongoing investigation by regulators on his treatment of internal whistleblowers. The U.K. Financial Conduct Authority opened an investigation in 2017 looking at Staley's alleged attempt to find out the name of the employee that wrote a letter raising concerns about the recruitment of a senior official by the bank. The FCA was due to publish the results of its investigation last October but is yet to do so.

column91: France, Germany, Hungary, Italy, Romania and Britain will be taken to court over their failure to respect limits for nitrogen dioxide (NO2) The move follows a summit in January in which the EU said it would get tough on member states that were still in breach of targets. Spain, Slovakia and the Czech Republic avoided court by promising measures that would allow them to live up to EU air quality rules.
column92: South Korea says it scrambled jets to intercept a Chinese incursion. It would be at least the third such incident this year. China generally says that it has no hostile intent. However the government has said drills near Taiwan are aimed at sending the message that there will be consequences if it tries to push for formal independence. The Chinese Foreign Ministry said in February the flights were completely in line with international law and practice.

column94: Suburban Propane Partners, L.P. declared a quarterly distribution of $0.60 per Common Unit for the three months ended . This quarterly distribution rate equates to an annualized rate of $2.40 per common unit. The distribution is payable on to Common Unitholders of record as of . There is a withholding requirement at the highest applicable effective tax rates for foreign partners.
column95: Stuart Bowers will work on Tesla's Autopilot software and other projects. Bowers' job at Snap, monetization engineering, involved the social media company's advertising system. Tesla has seen the departure of several senior executives and also is flattening its management structure as it aims to clear up production bottlenecks related to its new Model 3 sedan. Snap confirmed the move and said that Bowers had a passion for robotics.
column96: Sage Therapeutics is a clinical-stage biopharmaceutical company developing novel medicines to treat life-altering central nervous system (CNS) disorders. The company will host a conference call and live webcast on Thursday, at 8:00 A.M. ET to report its fourth quarter and full year 2017 financial results and to discuss recent business updates. column97: More than 270 pages and accounts operated by the same Russian organization which attempted to sway the 2016 U.S. presidential election. Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg said the company had found evidence the Internet Research Agency (IRA) had been attempting to manipulate public opinion in Russia through several Facebook and Instagram accounts. The IRA had also "repeatedly acted deceptively and tried to manipulate people" in the US and Europe in the past, Zuckerberg said.
column98: SoftBank Group Corp says it wants to list its Japanese telecoms unit this year. The company flagged last month that it was considering listing the business, seeking to raise a reported $18 billion. SoftBank has long relied on its domestic telecoms business, which makes up a third of overall sales but two-thirds of profit. It did not release a forecast for the current business year, saying there were too many uncertain factors.

column100: S&P Global has completed the previously announced acquisition of Kensho Technologies Inc. Kensho is a leading edge provider of next-generation analytics, artificial intelligence, machine learning, and data visualization systems. The acquisition was announced on . S&P is the leading provider of transparent and independent ratings, benchmarks, analytics and data to the capital and commodity markets worldwide. The Company has approximately 20,000 employees in 31 countries.
